page.title: 15Trees and plants, Craignish.
page.content: The most common trees are ash, birch, hawthorn, rowan, sycamore and willow. Alder, blackthorn, hazel, larch, lime and wych elm also grow, mainly in 'groves'.In areas constantly exposed to prevailing winds the trees grow into gnarled and twisted shapes, some barely gaining a 'foothold' on the exposed rocks. Large areas of the Kilmartin side of the loch have been planted with sitka spruce. Bracken, broom, gorse, heather and rhododendrons grow on the higher ground, with the fragrant bog myrtle abundant on damp land. On some of the islands and roadside verges Spring flowers grow in such profusion that they give a 'haze' of colour when seen from a distance. First the white of snowdrops, then primrose yellow, bluebells and later the pink of massed campions.
